thread.title: Man who persistently led Oregon police on chases admits he possessed pipe bombs
thread.title_full: Man who persistently led Oregon police on chases admits he possessed pipe bombs | OregonLive.com

author: Bryan Denson | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Man who persistently led Oregon police on chases admits he possessed pipe bombs
text:
The man who led police on a series of auto chases across western Oregon last fall, once throwing a bag of pipe bombs out the window, pleaded guilty in a federal courtroom Monday to possessing unregistered explosives.
Neal Allen Panschow, 44, admitted to U.S. District Judge Michael H. Simon that six times between Sept. 17, 2014 and Dec. 16, 2014 he knowingly possessed pipe bombs.
Neal Allen Panschow Columbia County Jail Simon set Panschow's sentencing for Jan. 12. Under the terms of a plea agreement, he is expected to serve nearly six years in prison. But under federal sentencing guidelines, Simon could sentence him to as many as nine years.
Panschow, who was held Monday in the Columbia County Jail, is suspected of persistent run-ins with Oregon authorities, including a felony charge of fleeing police in Tillamook County in March 2014.
Portland police caught sight of him on Dec. 16, when officers witnessed his Honda Civic swerving on Southeast 52 nd Avenue. They quickly learned the car was stolen and that its driver was suspected of assaulting a police officer in Lake Oswego. When they tried to stop the car, it sped up and they lost him.
A man in the 4600 block of Southeast Flavel Drive flagged them down, saying he saw something fly out of the passenger window of the Civic. Officers later recovered a Ziploc plastic bag that held two pipe bombs. As the Portland Metropolitan Explosive Disposal Unit moved in, two more of the destructive devices were found a couple of blocks away.
But investigators caught a break. They learned that Panschow had been caught on surveillance video at a Plaid Pantry in Northeast Portland on Dec. 16, about 35 minutes after he threw pipe bombs out of his car, according to the criminal complaint.
Police arrested Panschow five days later.
-- Bryan Denson
bdenson@oregonian.com
